GLEANINGS,

1t is undoubtedly very remarNaDle phc-
nomenen, that the earth, when dug to the
depth of eight or ten i.et or more, produces
many sorts of plants, provided it Is advanta
eeously exposed to the sun, but what IS more
extraordinary, is, that this new vegetation
frequently affords plants of kinds which
have never been remarked in the country.
1t is natural to ask, whence came these
rlanty? Can it be admitted tha. the seeds
of these new plants were contained III the
several kinds of earth! But could ali those
seeds, which had been perhaps above three
thousand years under ground, without hav-
ing ever been exposed to the action OF the
sun, have preserved the power OF general,
ing. If we strew ashes on high and ARID
heaths, we shall see sometime afterwards
clover and vetches growing there, though
these two plants had never before been
seen on those places. Shall we believe that
the seeds Of the clover and vetches were III
the ground, and only waited for stimulus
to germmate. But how did the seeds come
theres We know that high and arid heaths
never produce clover: it cannot therefore
be considered as proceeding from plant
which formerly grew there. But even oiu
we admit the possibility that these kinds of
earth NAV contain clover seed, TINS opinion
cannot be maintained in some parts OF East
Friesland, where wild clover is made to
grow BY strewing pearlashcs Oh peat-marsh-
es.-BulLetM UniUerSel.

AS an anonymous production of this char
acter, the work is unworthy Of further no.

PHILADELPHIA, 7th No. 2oM.

On the American side of the river there IS
very extensive Hotel and boarding house
kept by Gen. Whitney; on the British SIDE
is another. kept by Mr.. John Brown. There
is now project formed to construct car
riage rocd down each precipitous bank, to
the water, for the purpose OF coming with
coaches near til Falls. The road is to be
cxcavated chiefly from the rock in the bank S,
and is to descend one foot in ten feet, and
will reach about quarter OF mile il gau.
ing the bottom. 1t will be protected by !
strong railing, and be sufficiently wide at re-
cesscs for carriages to pass. This euterpri1e
will be amply repaid by the immense ferry
ing during the fashionable season." 1t is
mentioned as somewhat remarkable that
there are no insects on the Sc, cral islands in
the vicinity.

ry unassuming and courteous gentleman"

when he speaks it is to the point.

EMBELLIsAED WITH
lcDitndd Quurto EngrHuings.

AT a very large and respectable MeetinB OK
the Citizens of the State of Delaware, friendly
to Manufactures and Agriculture, convened by
public notice, at the Town Hall, in the Borough
of Wilmington, July 81, 1s27-Wm Cooch, esq.
was c~lled to the chair, and James Candy was ap-
pointed secretary.


On mntlon, it was Resoleed, That the Chair
man appoint committe of five to report resolu
tons expressive of the senses of this meetng:---
Whcrcupon, Caleb Kirk, w. P. Brobson, Rch-
ard Mansfield, Charles j Du Pont, and Isaac w.
Gibbs, were appointed. The said committee
after being some time absent, returned with the
following t-whichTafter being read by par
agraphs, and considered, was unanimously adopt
ed


The Committee appointed by this meeting,.
report for adoption, the following preamble and
resolutons:-1he great importance OF the inter-
ests of Agriculture and Manufactures, to the in.
dependence and prosperity of the United Statess
is too obvious to require proof they must be ad.
mitted to be essential to our happiness in time of
peace, and to our safety and glory, in.war. The
employment of our own in preference to foreign
labor; the creation of an home market for the
products of every branch of our Domestic Indus
try, thereby quickening the energies of Agri-
culture and Commerce; and the liberal protec.
~
eign competition, should be among the primary
duties of the government of the Union. The
Committee consider these Objects like those OF
the army and navy, of internal improvements
and the general system of national defence, to
be cardinal objects in the policy Of the General
Government, to be dealt with, and fostered,
and promoted under its auspices, according to
the means and exigencies of the Country.


The progress of these great interests in the
IT.,tz =. al. 1o14
the general prosperity which has uniformly fol.
lowed in their track, show that they are already
under the sound action of public sentiment, and
have taken too deep root in the interests and at
fections of the people, to be easily destroyed.


The Committee, therefore, recommend the
adoption of the following resolutions:


l. Resolved, That the employment of our
own III preference to foreign labor; the protec-
ton of the labor of our own citizens against for.
eign labor and foreign competition; and the cre-
alton Of home market for the products of every
branch Of our domestic industry, are primary OBJ
.iects Of every good government, and in pecu
| liar manner of that of the United States.
| g. ReSoiped, That the protection of Ameri-


can Manufactures is, in the opinion of this meet


ing, the true and honest policy of this nation,
that the truth of this proposition is every day
demonstrated, by the Aourishing condition of
every potion of our country where manufactur-
ing establishments are in successful progress
a condition not confined to the manufacturer
himself, but participated in by every other
branch of industry within the sphere of its inhu-
ence, and especially by the farmer, thus exhib.
itnE the intimate Union subsistng between the
two great interests of Agriculture and Manufac-
tures; and that while we cordially approve Of the
policy, we entertain no doubt of the constitu-
tonal power of Congress to legslate upon a
subject which was deemed peculiar object of
their care by Washington, Jefferson, Madison and
Monroe, and upon which congress has exercis
ed the right of legislation from the origin of the
government to the present day.


3. Res0irea, That we regard the doctrine
contained in the proceedings recently promul.
gated by the Legislature Of Virginia, denying to
congress ''any power whatever to protect do
mestic manufactures" as faacious and visiona,
ry in the extreme-as contrary to the best inter
ests and happiness of this nations as it is repug-
nant to the true intention and correct exposition
of the instrument which it assumes to interpret
-contradictcd by the concurring opinions of the
fathers of the Constitution itself Washington,
Hamilton and Madison, and by the uniform prac-
tice Of every administration which has acted un-
der that constitution.


/ 4. ReS0Iped, That whatever differences Of
opinion may exist as TO some Of the provisions of
the bill which passed the house of representa-.
tives during the last session of Congress, entitled
san act for the alteration of the acts imposing
duties on imports" we regard the general prn-
ciple Of support to so important branch ofman-
ufacture as that of wooen, as measure pecu-
larly calculated to promot. the interests of the
agrculturist and the manufacturer, by the pro-
lection it secured to the manufacturer of coarse
woollens, and to the produce of the raw material.


S. Resolred, That this meeting cordially ac-
cept the invitation of the Pennsylvania Society
! Of Manufactures and the Mechanic Arts, to ap-
point delegation to attend ebe General Con-
yenton at Harrisburg, on the 30th inst. for the
purpose of delberatng on the measures proper
to be taken in the present depressed state of
the woollen manufacture and the market for
wool, and such other manufactures as require
Legislative encouragement-and that William
Cooch, +. |. du Pont; James Candy, DR.. Arnold
Nautlain, Andrew Gray, VIM. w. Young, John
Higgins, James Riddle, Philip Reybold, Jona-
than Jenkins, Spencer Williams, Kendall Batson,
and VIM. d. NAPLES, be appointed Delegates
from this State, for the purpose expressed in this
resolution.


| 6. Hesolued, That the aforesaid delegates


have power to supply any vacancy which may


occur in their number.


| z. Resolred, That the Secretary be request


ed to give notice to the respective delegates,


of their appointment; and also, to furnish the


chairman of the delegation with an authenticat-


ed copy Of these proceedings.


g. Resolpsd, That we cordially unite with


the friends of Agriculture and Manufactures in


different parts of the Union, in an expression of
PUBLIC MEETING.

The State Convention of Manufacturers,
Wool growers, Farmers, and Mechanics
held at the Town Hall in this Borough, on
Saturday last, 2lst inst. for the purpose OF
appointing delegates to represent this State
in thc General Convention to be held at Har-
risburg, on the 50th inst was numerously at
tended. We do not know when we before
witnes ssrd larger body of our fellow citi-
zens assembled upon any similar occasion
The greatest order and harmony existed ana
business was transacted in manner hiShiy
creditable to the meeting.


The Delegates frcm the Eastern States to
the Convention are on their way to Harris
burg. Mr.. Everett. one of the Boston dele"
cation, it is said, will not be able to attend
as he is confined to his bed by a severe at
tack Of fever.

DELAWARE ADVERTISER.
Thursday, July 26, 1897.

The following is a cure for Felons:-- Take
QUICK, or unslacked lime; slack 1t IN soap;
bind on a plaster of it the size OF smai
bean: change it every half hour for three
bours This will draw it out, and leave the
hone and ioint perfectly sound. Having tried
the experiment on myself ana others' anu
nrver having known it to fail, think it may
be recommended to the public.

Saratoga Springs, July -, 1927.


Mn Uear------: have been amusing my
self for the last three day by scraping ac-
ounntancc with all the individuals who have
repaired hithcr to seek health in the water
of Congress or Colombia Spring have be-
come hail fellow with AL the e%iles from
pandora's box--l have formed familiar
acquaintance with dropsr, llrer-complaint,
scoriula and DYSPEPSIA. 10 see these dsor'
ders in all their charms, il is only necessary
to 60 down to the Bathing Housc at eleven
o'clock; you will find them Oh the stoop, All
waiting their turn tn take a duchlng from
the shower bath. BY way OF good fellow.
shin, took a bath myself Yesterday, (altho
Ihave no complaint, except a consumption
Of the purse,') and was almost sca!dcd to
death BY the Internal carelessness o! the at
tendant. You have seen shower bath
When YOU are prepared you place your ooe'y
under seive, and pull string whlch turhs
a tub, and down comes the shower. or
dered a warn shower bath. Now this may
he prepared in two ways, either by warm
ing the fluid to proper degree, or by mix
;nr boiling and cold water. What docs the
man do but pour in the boiling water first,
and Just as pulled the string, shouted "tor
heavens sake don't pull, the cold water
ISN'T poured int 1t was too latc--down
came the hot water, and out jumped your
scaldcd friend, swearing like Persian grcn-
adler. was absolutely parboiled, and my
/ face to-day is the image Of hideousness.-
You may infer that have not honorcd the
drawing room with my presence since the
catastrophe.


Some of the invalids here are amusing
characters. One of them is a Bostonian,
whose leg was broken last winter, by tumb-
ling from stage. His doctor, by msman-
agement, set it awry, and being unable to
cure his patient, shipped him Oft to the
Springs was quite amused to hear DR.. )
the resident physician. talk to him; my
dear fellow" said he, "do you suppose the
Congress water is going to set your leg, OF
amputate it. in case of notification Il
there be iron in the water, it is not iror
manufactured into surgical Instruments
&c back to Boston and tell youl Doctor no
TO send any more of his incurables here, Il
throw the blame off from himself" DIR. ;
complains grievously of the course pursue'
BY divers members of the killing art. When
ever they have patient with whsm the
know not what to do, they send him to Sara
toga if he des---so--it is not tho fault of hi
original physician--if he RECEIVERS, the cred
it is all their own, for sending him, Just j
the nick Of time, to the Springs. Thu, d
S. (who is an excellent physician. and a We
ry agreeable companion is debited with a
The deaths, and deprived of the credit of a
the cures.


There is little Frenchman here froT
Canada, whom the dropsy has converted III
70 the form of balloon. His Hypocratd
oEthc North, finding him "past redemption
sent him hther. lie jumped ont of til
stage and made strishtway to the Spring.
After quaffing some dozen glasses Of the wa
ter, he marched up the hill, to seek quai
ters, His room adjoins mine. BY night-fA
he was quite unwell, and sent for the Doc
tor Like Billy Lackaday, he told his stor
N most moving manner. The Doctor To-


al patience, aud pcrpctrated an oath, "Hav


you not got water enough in your body,
said he, without coming here and guzzlln
the whole Spring at one potation!' lie the
decorated his patients body with numhe
@bNsters, and was kept awake all nlsl
eythe groanings and frequent CALCULATIONS


aelaS' which proceeded from the sutferir


scion Of Gaul


But enough of these details. I am al

Mremove the effects of my Semicoetion, al


u see fit to write again, my next will tre

Er;raet ofa letter .frem an Officer Of an
smrr,can Merchant Vessel, dated at


Lintn, March 20, 1927.


"On the list inst. there was battle be-
.ween five boats Of the American. aud Eng
iish laving in this port, and two Chinese
Mandarin Boats and one of their men OF
,var's Launches, occasioned by Pass Boat
coming down with orders for the AM ship
citizen, of New York, to proceed to Canton.
The Mapdarins took the pass boat, and
we're towing her towards the Chinese YES
seJs of war. when the Americans and Eng
,ish manned their boats, and went in pursuit.
In about half an hour the foremost boat
came up with them. Muskets were hrcd
and stones thrown from the Mandarin boats;
Int our other boats coming up, they began
"a attack, and succeeded in re-takins the
pass Boat and orders, and proceeded to the
ship Citizen. heard Oh the "a inst. that
there were two Mandsrins killed and TWEEN
~ wounded. There are three or four Chi
nese vessels of war lying here now, and
there are said to be thirty more coming
from town-distant 60 miles. We now lie
with all our guns double sbotted. ready tor
hattie. The vessels that are here, THINK
are more than a match for them. 1t VIII
nrobably put a stop to business tor some
time, at Wampon, where the vessels lie
that are bound to Canton. There are TWO
men, slightly hurt with stones, being thc
only ones injured, on our side, in TINS affair

very pretty, but sound very rd;cnlously,
in the pompcus style OF Spanish proclana
tions.


The Richmond Enquirer Of Tuesday week
sayS:--


"A letter has been received in this city
from a gentleman in Charlottesville, dated
on the 18th inst which states that Mr.. MAD
IsoN was taken extremely i'll with the Cho-
lcra Morbus on the night before; and that
on the morning of the 18th, at ] l o'clock, he
was TO better, Mr.. Monroe was with him,
and DR.. Dungleson was attending him. we
understand, from passenger who arrived
in last evenings charlottesville stage, that
Mr. Madison was much better. We rejoice
that the valuable life of this pure and il
lustrous man is spared to his grateful coun-
try"


lfcdical Prize Essay.--The prize OF a
silver cup Of the value of fifty dollars, OF.
fered by the Association of Physicians OF
Philadelphia, for the best ESSAY on Drop
sies,'' has been awarded to Doct James
Conquest Cross, of Fayctte County, Ken
lucky.


! When the Massachusetts, branch OF the
| Cincinnati Society was formed, it consisted
of three hundred and thirty-six members; 1t
has now. after period of A years, only
forty of the original members lett; iiitech
only of whom are able to attend the yearly


meeting Of the society.


The Hermione French schooner, with .9V


nerrocs on board, was captured at the Isle


du Prince, on the coast of Africa, by one ol
the ships OF war of the French squadron sta


toned in those seas. The schooner having
been sent to Cavenoc, was condemned ano
confiscated in that colony by the sentence ol


the tribunal of the first instance on the n s'


of March last, as having violated the ordi-
nance relative to the slave trade


Gen. Watswortl, of the State Of Sew-York
s said to have thirteen thousand sheep on hi'


farm

We learn that the Commissioners on the
part Of the State of New-York, tor defining
and settling the boundary between that
State and New-Jersey, met at Albany on
the 10Th inst, and adjourned to meet the n
Jersey Commissioners on the 1st OF August
at Newark. Itis to be hoped that this
Question which has so lorg occupied the at"
ten,ion Of both States. may now be settled
permanently, and to the satisfaction OF 0o'n
n,rt,es

Gen. Wadswortl, of the State OF New-fork'
Is said to have thirteen thousand sheep on ms
farm.

The Fredericksburg Herald states tha'
the health of Mr.. Madison is almost eh'l'e'
lyrcstnred,

full articles.headline: GLEANINGS,
full articles.article:
IT is proposed to establish an Academy in the
vicinity of Philadelphia, to be under the control
and patronage of the annual conference OF the
Methodist Episcopal Church.


In 1776 Mr.. Jefferson occupied the most west
erly house in philapelphia. is now the cen
tire of the city.


The Canadian red squirrels are crossing the
ST. Lawrence near ogdensburg, in vast quaint
ties despairing, as the Gazette thinks of ever OBJ
tanning the privileges Of citizenship under the re-
cent alien law ofthat province.


According to the official register of the U. S.
Navy, there are 791 officers in that service, viz.
81 Captains, 90 Masters Commandants, 228
Lieutenants, ~ Surgeons, 40 Surgeons mates,
~ purscrs, Chaplains, and 374 Milshipmen.


On the 7th instant, considerable damage was
done to the banks of the Chesapeake and Della
ware Canal, by an overflow Of the waters in the
meadows near the eastern termination of that
work.


There were 90 cases of yellow fever on board
the John Adams, arrived at Pensacola from Ma
sanzas.


New-Orleans remained healthy on the thir-
tieth u!t. The river had fallen about two feet.


From Havana we learn that the Spanish squad
ron under Commodore Isborde, sailed on the
2i instant on a cruise. Commodore Porter was
still at Key West, but the two brgs were out
cruising


Under the provisions of the Corporation
laws on the aubjcct, several hundred dogs
have been put to death this season in Phia
delphia.
| Earthquake.-A shock of an earthquake
was sensibly felt in Frank fort, kentucky, on
the morning OF the 9TH inst little alter 6
o'clock

full articles.headline:
n--E| ]. u. q EScNo1.4gr1-.sss3;lI ~. 8 =.

EQUIVOCAL. PRODUCTION OF


PLAN rs.
full articles.article:
1t is undoubtedly very remarNaDle phc-
nomenen, that the earth, when dug to the
depth of eight or ten i.et or more, produces
many sorts of plants, provided it Is advanta
eeously exposed to the sun, but what IS more
extraordinary, is, that this new vegetation
frequently affords plants of kinds which
have never been remarked in the country.
1t is natural to ask, whence came these
rlanty? Can it be admitted tha. the seeds
of these new plants were contained III the
several kinds of earth! But could ali those
seeds, which had been perhaps above three
thousand years under ground, without hav-
ing ever been exposed to the action OF the
sun, have preserved the power OF general,
ing. If we strew ashes on high and ARID
heaths, we shall see sometime afterwards
clover and vetches growing there, though
these two plants had never before been
seen on those places. Shall we believe that
the seeds Of the clover and vetches were III
the ground, and only waited for stimulus
to germmate. But how did the seeds come
theres We know that high and arid heaths
never produce clover: it cannot therefore
be considered as proceeding from plant
which formerly grew there. But even oiu
we admit the possibility that these kinds of
earth NAV contain clover seed, TINS opinion
cannot be maintained in some parts OF East
Friesland, where wild clover is made to
grow BY strewing pearlashcs Oh peat-marsh-
es.-BulLetM UniUerSel.

nnt,. circumstances such as these, attending the

full articles.headline: For tie TYiimington,an.
full articles.article:
Mr. Editor--It appears that the hints sug-
gestcd in your paper of the 18th and address
ed to the Watering Committee, has given
umbrage to some choleric gentleman, who
undertakes" (gratuitous, prssume,) to de-
fend at the point of hls---pen, whatever
plan the Committee may adopt. Your cor


respondent p, to say the least of hun, has


manifested more petuence than prudence,
or he would not have exposed himself SO e.
gregiously. He tells us "the mill is allowed
a good and sufficient head OF water for driv-
ing a stone OF certain dimensions with the
necessary machinery for manufacturing
tleman, what is to prevent all the water in
The race from flowing upon the wheel? why a
gate, to he sure' \ gate to open and yet make
to aperture What way can yen measure the
amount of that sufficient quantity when ap-
Piled to other purposes than the milling, but
/ ty an equal aperture. whether that be Some
hundred and five" or5o0 square inches, does
not in the least degree affect the correctness OF
the position took in my last, viz: that it is
more eligible to reserve a portion of the wa
ter for the supply Of the pump, after it has
passed the gate, or, If he please, part oi
this Sufficient quantity" b.f2rc it has f..llen
on tho wheel, than to raise a column an adj
dtional is feet with all the power allowedi
and for this byious reason. that it will re-
7 quire, with the most perfect III chnery o


the construction proposed, at least 5 gallon
OIL the wheel to raise two gallons to an equa
any doubts upon the subject, ! hope, if MOI
| for the interest Of the Borough, at least fol
their own credits sake, that they will consult
scientific and practical men upon this point


when it will be found il strict accordance
with sound philosophy and experience. But
=. tells us "those gentlemen will doubtless
have enough to attend to without noticing
the z,hims Of every theorist," alluting TO the
practical hints thrown out in my last 1t
however, your correahonac." could have
taken Mc timr to examine, sobelly, he might
have discovered. instead OF "whlns" and
"theories," some useful facts and obvious
deductions; obvious at least to those whose
faculties had not become stultifed. If P
can prove them false, then he has discovered
the long sought perpetual motion and we
have no need of the mill. But as have nc
faith in his having made this discovery. ! car
see nothing to compensate for this loss o


hozvcr but the 79eigat OF his stupendous &C.
Mus. "

attacked, and their names dragged before
the public, while the author has cautiously
kept himself in ambush.


AS an anonymous production of this char
acter, the work is unworthy Of further no.
tice. Its obj ct is sufficiently apparent from
its title, and is still more obvious from
slight examination OF its contents-to support
the sinking cause of a harty in the Society
of Friends by endeavoring to asperse and
stigmatize the great body of its members.


II, however, the author or authors of the
pamphlet, will have so much regard to cor
rect and honourable principle as to favour
the public, through the medium of this or
some other paper. with their names, their
work shall receive as much attention as they
may desire.


THOMAS M'CLINTOCK.


PHILADELPHIA, 7th No. 2oM.

full articles.headline: NIAGARA FALLS.
full articles.article:
On the American side of the river there IS
very extensive Hotel and boarding house
kept by Gen. Whitney; on the British SIDE
is another. kept by Mr.. John Brown. There
is now project formed to construct car
riage rocd down each precipitous bank, to
the water, for the purpose OF coming with
coaches near til Falls. The road is to be
cxcavated chiefly from the rock in the bank S,
and is to descend one foot in ten feet, and
will reach about quarter OF mile il gau.
ing the bottom. 1t will be protected by !
strong railing, and be sufficiently wide at re-
cesscs for carriages to pass. This euterpri1e
will be amply repaid by the immense ferry
ing during the fashionable season." 1t is
mentioned as somewhat remarkable that
there are no insects on the Sc, cral islands in
the vicinity.

A letter from Saratoga Springs, says -
"The Ex-King of Spain (Joseph Buonaparte)
and the two sons of "him Of the snow-whitc
plumc," (Murat) are here. The younger
Murat is very handsome man. and is We
ry unassuming and courteous gentleman"
Buonaparte is said to be an amiable, dignifed
and courteous man; not much of talker, but
when he speaks it is to the point.

sosn as ripe enough, and husk it as soon as
the corn will admit; cut down and bear OF
the stalks. to let the sun upon the turnips,
and the sweetness of the fodder will COM
pensate for the labor. Take in the turnlps
about the middle of December. BY pursu.
ing these directions, corn of forty bushels to
the acre, will produce 80 or 100 bushels OF
turnips at the same time; these for mich
cows and sheep will be ofparticular impor-
tance.

and good, in the heat ct summer, oy hsn.y

it in high and windy room; therefore,

full articles.article:
This work is intended as all agreeable and in
structivc companion for the pa lour, and ali ap-
propriate attendant at the Toilet


No cxcrtion will be spared to render "TilE
SOUVENIR in all respects, worthy the patron
age Of the public, both as a cheap and elegant
emporium of useful and interesting information,
and valuable repository of choice specimens OF
Miscellaneous literature. Strict attention will
be bestowed on the moral tendency Of "rIIE
SOUVENIR" and q constant watchiuness pre-
served over the cause and interests of virtue.


a portion Of the contents will be as follows:


l. TALES, original and selected; ESSAYS,
moral, humorous and scientific p OETRY, origin
al and selected from the best American and For
eign publications.; BIOGRAPHICAL SKETCH
ES of distinguished persons, male and female,
particularly the latter; ANECDOTES, Bon MDts
&c. &c The misinai matter necessary for this
department of our paper will be furnished by
individuals who are advantagcously known to
the public through the medium Of their Litera.
~ productions; besides the numerous CO res
pondcnts who may be expected to contribute


II. LLANY-lnteresting items of n-
tclligence, foreign and domestic occurrences,
deaths, marriages, &c.


ILL., ENGRAvINGS. The first number of
cyery month will be embellished with splendid
guarto COPPER-pLATE ENGRAVING, fitted
to the size of the work, among which will be the
following:


Alhambra. Ancient Palace of the Moorish
Kings in Spain. View Of the Permanent Fridge
over the Shuylkll. 4Etna, from the Gardens Of
the Prince of Biscaria. View of Petersburgh -
Arch Street Ferry, Philadelphia. Paraclete,
founded bv Abelard. Giants Causeway and
Bridge Of llridon. State Prison, Auburn, New
York. Tynwald Hill, Isle of Man. Burning
Fountain, one of the seven wonders OF Daphlny.
Grotto Of Oselos. Temple OF Pluto. Pont Du
Gard near Nismes, I.angucdoc. Sanssure's as
cent of Mont Rlanc. Cascade near oysans, Dal-
nhiny. Desert of the Grand Chartrense. East
prosnect Of Giants Causeway. Castle of Sego-
vim. snain. Lake Of Killarney from Kenmure
Park


Each subscriber will be furnished yearly with
seventeen superior Copper-rhte Engrayings,
the price Of which fpurchased singly would be
more than double the annual cost Of the entire
work.
Nv. THE TOILET I'm addition to the usual
Literary matter contained in similar publications,
the Proprietor has completed an arrangement
| by which he will be enabled to furnish correct
descriptions Of the prevailing fashions, both tor
eign and domestic, illustrated with elegant en-.
cravings, besides the regular series, once ineach
quarter; places of fashionable resorts sketches OF
life manners, &C. &c at the earliest possible Pc
r;od. and from the most authentic sources.


v. Editors departments Notices of passing
events; The Drama; New fuDAcauonsi elltl
cisms, Reviews, &c. &c.


TERNEs.


uTuF SOUVENIR" will be published ever,
WEDNESDAY, on extra-medium fne white
paner. printed with new and elegant type, anS
decorated, in addition to the engrayings alluded
to above, with many appropriate Embellishments
Each number will comprise eight pages, cut
stitched and expressly adapted for binding. A
the expiration of every year, or the ciosc OF vol
ume. subscribers will be furnished gratis, witt
a general index ofthe contents, and u handsome
ly engraved title-paSe.


Price of subscription 50 so per annun, raya
BILE in advance. Postmasters and Others out c
the city, procuring five subscribers and becou
ing responsible for the payment, will be entitle
to q sixth copy gratis


The Copper-plate embellishments will be 81
. perintended by the publisher, and the typ
graphical part of this work will be under the e'
/, elusive direction of Mcssrs. Atkinson & Alexal
der, who have been SO long known to the publ
as able and cnterprsing artlzans, that it is e'
5 tirely unnecessary to say that so tar as they al
= = concerned, there can be no doubt as to the c
e,ance of its execution; and with regard to h
own share Of the arrangements, the pupHsh
binds himself, in case he should fail to peHof


any essential part of his undertaking to retuT


the price Of subscription.


PHILLIP PRICE Jr. Philadelphia.
l. Subscriptions will be received !
NJ this Office, where a specimen
IS as the Work may be seen,

full articles.headline: PUBLIC MEETING.
full articles.article:
AT a very large and respectable MeetinB OK
the Citizens of the State of Delaware, friendly
to Manufactures and Agriculture, convened by
public notice, at the Town Hall, in the Borough
of Wilmington, July 81, 1s27-Wm Cooch, esq.
was c~lled to the chair, and James Candy was ap-
pointed secretary.


On mntlon, it was Resoleed, That the Chair
man appoint committe of five to report resolu
tons expressive of the senses of this meetng:---
Whcrcupon, Caleb Kirk, w. P. Brobson, Rch-
ard Mansfield, Charles j Du Pont, and Isaac w.
Gibbs, were appointed. The said committee
after being some time absent, returned with the
following t-whichTafter being read by par
agraphs, and considered, was unanimously adopt
ed


The Committee appointed by this meeting,.
report for adoption, the following preamble and
resolutons:-1he great importance OF the inter-
ests of Agriculture and Manufactures, to the in.
dependence and prosperity of the United Statess
is too obvious to require proof they must be ad.
mitted to be essential to our happiness in time of
peace, and to our safety and glory, in.war. The
employment of our own in preference to foreign
labor; the creation of an home market for the
products of every branch of our Domestic Indus
try, thereby quickening the energies of Agri-
culture and Commerce; and the liberal protec.
~
eign competition, should be among the primary
duties of the government of the Union. The
Committee consider these Objects like those OF
the army and navy, of internal improvements
and the general system of national defence, to
be cardinal objects in the policy Of the General
Government, to be dealt with, and fostered,
and promoted under its auspices, according to
the means and exigencies of the Country.


The progress of these great interests in the
IT.,tz =. al. 1o14
the general prosperity which has uniformly fol.
lowed in their track, show that they are already
under the sound action of public sentiment, and
have taken too deep root in the interests and at
fections of the people, to be easily destroyed.


The Committee, therefore, recommend the
adoption of the following resolutions:


l. Resolved, That the employment of our
own III preference to foreign labor; the protec-
ton of the labor of our own citizens against for.
eign labor and foreign competition; and the cre-
alton Of home market for the products of every
branch Of our domestic industry, are primary OBJ
.iects Of every good government, and in pecu
| liar manner of that of the United States.
| g. ReSoiped, That the protection of Ameri-


can Manufactures is, in the opinion of this meet


ing, the true and honest policy of this nation,
that the truth of this proposition is every day
demonstrated, by the Aourishing condition of
every potion of our country where manufactur-
ing establishments are in successful progress
a condition not confined to the manufacturer
himself, but participated in by every other
branch of industry within the sphere of its inhu-
ence, and especially by the farmer, thus exhib.
itnE the intimate Union subsistng between the
two great interests of Agriculture and Manufac-
tures; and that while we cordially approve Of the
policy, we entertain no doubt of the constitu-
tonal power of Congress to legslate upon a
subject which was deemed peculiar object of
their care by Washington, Jefferson, Madison and
Monroe, and upon which congress has exercis
ed the right of legislation from the origin of the
government to the present day.


3. Res0irea, That we regard the doctrine
contained in the proceedings recently promul.
gated by the Legislature Of Virginia, denying to
congress ''any power whatever to protect do
mestic manufactures" as faacious and visiona,
ry in the extreme-as contrary to the best inter
ests and happiness of this nations as it is repug-
nant to the true intention and correct exposition
of the instrument which it assumes to interpret
-contradictcd by the concurring opinions of the
fathers of the Constitution itself Washington,
Hamilton and Madison, and by the uniform prac-
tice Of every administration which has acted un-
der that constitution.


/ 4. ReS0Iped, That whatever differences Of
opinion may exist as TO some Of the provisions of
the bill which passed the house of representa-.
tives during the last session of Congress, entitled
san act for the alteration of the acts imposing
duties on imports" we regard the general prn-
ciple Of support to so important branch ofman-
ufacture as that of wooen, as measure pecu-
larly calculated to promot. the interests of the
agrculturist and the manufacturer, by the pro-
lection it secured to the manufacturer of coarse
woollens, and to the produce of the raw material.


S. Resolred, That this meeting cordially ac-
cept the invitation of the Pennsylvania Society
! Of Manufactures and the Mechanic Arts, to ap-
point delegation to attend ebe General Con-
yenton at Harrisburg, on the 30th inst. for the
purpose of delberatng on the measures proper
to be taken in the present depressed state of
the woollen manufacture and the market for
wool, and such other manufactures as require
Legislative encouragement-and that William
Cooch, +. |. du Pont; James Candy, DR.. Arnold
Nautlain, Andrew Gray, VIM. w. Young, John
Higgins, James Riddle, Philip Reybold, Jona-
than Jenkins, Spencer Williams, Kendall Batson,
and VIM. d. NAPLES, be appointed Delegates
from this State, for the purpose expressed in this
resolution.


| 6. Hesolued, That the aforesaid delegates


have power to supply any vacancy which may


occur in their number.


| z. Resolred, That the Secretary be request


ed to give notice to the respective delegates,


of their appointment; and also, to furnish the


chairman of the delegation with an authenticat-


ed copy Of these proceedings.


g. Resolpsd, That we cordially unite with


the friends of Agriculture and Manufactures in


different parts of the Union, in an expression of

full articles.headline:
TTdE yVTLn3IM gsT ON1AM


ANN
DELAWARE ADVERTISER.

Thursday, July 26, 1897.
full articles.article:
The State Convention of Manufacturers,
Wool growers, Farmers, and Mechanics
held at the Town Hall in this Borough, on
Saturday last, 2lst inst. for the purpose OF
appointing delegates to represent this State
in thc General Convention to be held at Har-
risburg, on the 50th inst was numerously at
tended. We do not know when we before
witnes ssrd larger body of our fellow citi-
zens assembled upon any similar occasion
The greatest order and harmony existed ana
business was transacted in manner hiShiy
creditable to the meeting.


The Delegates frcm the Eastern States to
the Convention are on their way to Harris
burg. Mr.. Everett. one of the Boston dele"
cation, it is said, will not be able to attend
as he is confined to his bed by a severe at
tack Of fever.

full articles.headline:
From the Zion's Herald.
CJJRF. FOR FELSNS.
full articles.article:
The following is a cure for Felons:-- Take
QUICK, or unslacked lime; slack 1t IN soap;
bind on a plaster of it the size OF smai
bean: change it every half hour for three
bours This will draw it out, and leave the
hone and ioint perfectly sound. Having tried
the experiment on myself ana others' anu
nrver having known it to fail, think it may
be recommended to the public.


THOS: G. BROWN.
Boston, June l6, 1927.

full articles.headline: DIED.
full articles.article:
On Sunday afternoon last, at N. York, after a
short and painful illness, WILLIAM CHAM
BERs, VI. u. so celebrated for lis cure OF intem-
ncrauCe.

full articles.headline: Saratoga SPRINGS. July -, 1927
full articles.article:
ouly ones injured, on our side, in this affair


Saratoga Springs, July -, 1927.


Mn Uear------: have been amusing my
self for the last three day by scraping ac-
ounntancc with all the individuals who have
repaired hithcr to seek health in the water
of Congress or Colombia Spring have be-
come hail fellow with AL the e%iles from
pandora's box--l have formed familiar
acquaintance with dropsr, llrer-complaint,
scoriula and DYSPEPSIA. 10 see these dsor'
ders in all their charms, il is only necessary
to 60 down to the Bathing Housc at eleven
o'clock; you will find them Oh the stoop, All
waiting their turn tn take a duchlng from
the shower bath. BY way OF good fellow.
shin, took a bath myself Yesterday, (altho
Ihave no complaint, except a consumption
Of the purse,') and was almost sca!dcd to
death BY the Internal carelessness o! the at
tendant. You have seen shower bath
When YOU are prepared you place your ooe'y
under seive, and pull string whlch turhs
a tub, and down comes the shower. or
dered a warn shower bath. Now this may
he prepared in two ways, either by warm
ing the fluid to proper degree, or by mix
;nr boiling and cold water. What docs the
man do but pour in the boiling water first,
and Just as pulled the string, shouted "tor
heavens sake don't pull, the cold water
ISN'T poured int 1t was too latc--down
came the hot water, and out jumped your
scaldcd friend, swearing like Persian grcn-
adler. was absolutely parboiled, and my
/ face to-day is the image Of hideousness.-
You may infer that have not honorcd the
drawing room with my presence since the
catastrophe.


Some of the invalids here are amusing
characters. One of them is a Bostonian,
whose leg was broken last winter, by tumb-
ling from stage. His doctor, by msman-
agement, set it awry, and being unable to
cure his patient, shipped him Oft to the
Springs was quite amused to hear DR.. )
the resident physician. talk to him; my
dear fellow" said he, "do you suppose the
Congress water is going to set your leg, OF
amputate it. in case of notification Il
there be iron in the water, it is not iror
manufactured into surgical Instruments
&c back to Boston and tell youl Doctor no
TO send any more of his incurables here, Il
throw the blame off from himself" DIR. ;
complains grievously of the course pursue'
BY divers members of the killing art. When
ever they have patient with whsm the
know not what to do, they send him to Sara
toga if he des---so--it is not tho fault of hi
original physician--if he RECEIVERS, the cred
it is all their own, for sending him, Just j
the nick Of time, to the Springs. Thu, d
S. (who is an excellent physician. and a We
ry agreeable companion is debited with a
The deaths, and deprived of the credit of a
the cures.


There is little Frenchman here froT
Canada, whom the dropsy has converted III
70 the form of balloon. His Hypocratd
oEthc North, finding him "past redemption
sent him hther. lie jumped ont of til
stage and made strishtway to the Spring.
After quaffing some dozen glasses Of the wa
ter, he marched up the hill, to seek quai
ters, His room adjoins mine. BY night-fA
he was quite unwell, and sent for the Doc
tor Like Billy Lackaday, he told his stor
N most moving manner. The Doctor To-


al patience, aud pcrpctrated an oath, "Hav


you not got water enough in your body,
said he, without coming here and guzzlln

"On the list inst. there was battle be-
.ween five boats Of the American. aud Eng
iish laving in this port, and two Chinese
Mandarin Boats and one of their men OF
,var's Launches, occasioned by Pass Boat
coming down with orders for the AM ship
citizen, of New York, to proceed to Canton.
The Mapdarins took the pass boat, and
we're towing her towards the Chinese YES
seJs of war. when the Americans and Eng
,ish manned their boats, and went in pursuit.
In about half an hour the foremost boat
came up with them. Muskets were hrcd
and stones thrown from the Mandarin boats;
Int our other boats coming up, they began
"a attack, and succeeded in re-takins the
pass Boat and orders, and proceeded to the
ship Citizen. heard Oh the "a inst. that
there were two Mandsrins killed and TWEEN
~ wounded. There are three or four Chi
nese vessels of war lying here now, and
there are said to be thirty more coming
from town-distant 60 miles. We now lie
with all our guns double sbotted. ready tor
hattie. The vessels that are here, THINK
are more than a match for them. 1t VIII
nrobably put a stop to business tor some
time, at Wampon, where the vessels lie
that are bound to Canton. There are TWO
men, slightly hurt with stones, being thc
only ones injured, on our side, in TINS affair

The Richmond Enquirer Of Tuesday week
sayS:--


"A letter has been received in this city
from a gentleman in Charlottesville, dated
on the 18th inst which states that Mr.. MAD
IsoN was taken extremely i'll with the Cho-
lcra Morbus on the night before; and that
on the morning of the 18th, at ] l o'clock, he
was TO better, Mr.. Monroe was with him,
and DR.. Dungleson was attending him. we
understand, from passenger who arrived
in last evenings charlottesville stage, that
Mr. Madison was much better. We rejoice
that the valuable life of this pure and il
lustrous man is spared to his grateful coun-
try"
